title-group.article-title: A new vibration approach of an elastic oval cylindrical shell with varying circumferential thickness

contrib-group.aff: Faculty of Science at Qena, Department of Mathematics, South Valley University, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: Mousa Khalifa Ahmed, Faculty of Science at Qena, Department of Mathematics, South Valley University, Egypt Email: mousa@japan.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A new vibration behavior is presented for an elastic oval cylindrical shell having circumferentially variable thickness with complex radius of curvature of an isotropic and orthotropic material. Based on the framework of the Flügge’s shell theory, the transfer matrix approach and the Romberg integration method, the governing equations of motion that have variable coefficients are formulated and solved. The analysis is formulated to overcome the mathematical difficulties related to mode coupling which comes from variable curvature and thickness of shell. The vibration equations of the shell are reduced to eight first-order differential equations in the circumferential coordinate, and by using the transfer matrix of the shell, these equations can be written in a matrix differential equation. The proposed model is adopted to get the vibration frequencies and the corresponding mode shapes for symmetric and anti-symmetric modes of vibration. The sensitivity of the frequency parameters and the bending deformations to the shell geometry, ovality parameter, thickness ratio, and orthotropic parameters corresponding to different types of vibration modes of shells is investigated.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, structural engineers have gradually become concerned with the analysis of cylindrical shells that have non-circular profiles and are found in many engineering applications, such as aerospace, mechanical engineering, nuclear, petrochemical, modern passenger airplanes, civil and marine structures. The frequencies and mode shapes of vibration of thin elastic shells essentially depend on some determining functions such as the radius of the curvature of the neutral surface, the shell thickness, the shape of the shell edges, and so forth. In simple cases when these functions are constant, the vibration deflection displacements occupy the entire shell surface. If the determining functions vary from point to point of the neutral surface then localization of the vibration modes lies near the weakest lines on the shell surface, which has less stiffness. These types of problems are difficult because the radius of its curvature varies with the circumferential coordinate; closed-form or analytic solutions cannot be obtained, in general, for this class of shells; and numerical or approximate techniques are necessary for their analysis. Vibration problems in structural dynamics have become more of a problem in recent years because the use of high strength material requires less material for load support-structures and components have become generally more slender and vibration-prone. The vibration response of shells of revolution has been studied by many researchers since the basic equations for this were established by Flügge (1934), Love (1944), and Rayleigh (1945). The best collection of documents can be found in Leissa (1973) in which more than 500 publications are analyzed and discussed in both linear and nonlinear vibration cases for circular cylindrical shells. Recently, other related references may be found in the well-known work of Markus (1988), Zhang et al. (2001), Li (2006), and Pellicano (2007). Some researchers have considerable interest in the study of vibration behavior of circular cylindrical shells with variable thickness (such as Duan and Koh, 2008; Sivadas and Ganesan, 1991; Suzuki, et al., 1981; Zhang and Xiang, 2006) in which investigations have been made into different forms of thickness, i.e. axial, circumferential and step-wise thickness variation. A few researchers have devoted their studies to vibration characteristics of non-uniform circular cylindrical shells with constant thickness (Ganapathi et al., 2004; Soldatos, 1999; Yamada et al., 1984, 1985) in which investigations have been made into different forms of radius of curvature, i.e. oval, elliptical, three and four-lobed cross-section. In contrast, the vibration study of non-uniform cylindrical shells with variable thickness has received much less attention, but some implementations are well documented by Suzuki and Leissa (1985), Mitao et al. (1996) and Khalifa (2010) in which their treatments have been modeled into different forms of shell theories. The vibration problems of cylindrical shells with an oval profile are rather limited, which is due to the difficulty introduced in governing equations of motion. Some researchers conducted their studies to such problems with constant or variable thickness, but they have used a simple form of curvature radius – one eccentricity parameter (such as Chen and Kempner, 1978; Culberson and Boyd, 1971; Ganapathi et al., 2003; Koumousis and Armenakas, 1983; Kumar and Singh, 1991; Soldatos and Tzivanidis, 1982). A treatise on the use of the transfer matrix approach for mechanical science problems is presented by Tesar and Fillo (1988). However, the vibration problem of the orthotropic oval cylindrical shells with thickness variation along the circumference with a complex radius of curvature does not appear to have been dealt with in the literature. This paper is to present the vibration characteristics of an elastic oval shell with radius of curvature having more than one degree terms of eccentricity parameter, using the transfer matrix approach and modeled on Flügge’s shell theory in conjunction with the Romberg integration method. The influences of the shell thickness ratios, ovality parameter, axial and circumferential rigidities parameters on the natural frequencies and mode shapes are examined. The results are cited in tabular and graphical forms for easy reference by researchers.

sec.title: 2. Theory and formulation of the problem
sec.p: It has been mentioned in the Introduction that the problem structure is modeled by Flügge’s theory. In order to have a better representation, the shell geometry and governing equations are made as separate parts. The formulation of these parts is presented below.

sec.title: 2.1. Geometric formulation
sec.p: We consider an orthotropic oval cylindrical shell and its material is linearly elastic.

The cross-section profile of the oval shell is expressed by the equation r = r0 f(θ), where r is the local varied radius along the cross-section mid-line, r0 is the reference radius of curvature, chosen to be the radius of a circle having the same circumference as the oval profile, and f(θ) is a prescribed function of θ and can be taken from Biing et al. (2009) as: (1) where 0 ≤ ε < 1 is the ovality parameter and measures the eccentricity of the cross-section of the shell, and such a function describes a doubly symmetric oval cross-section. The ovality parameter ε is expressed by the semi-major, a, and semi-minor, b, axes of the oval profile as: 1−(B/A)2,B=b/r0, B = b/r0 and A = a/r0.

The cylindrical coordinates (x, s, z) are taken to define the position of a point on the middle surface of the shell, as shown in Figure 1. The deflection displacements of the middle surface of the shell are denoted by u, υ and w in the longitudinal, circumferential and transverse directions, respectively. Its geometry is described by R, the radius of curvature of the middle surface, H, the thickness of the shell, and L, the axial length. We suppose that the shell thickness H at any point along the circumference is small and depends on the tangential angle α and takes the following form: (2) where α is the angle between the tangent τ(θ) at the origin of s, located at the end of the semi-major axis, a, and the one at any point on the centerline, and H0 is a small parameter, chosen to be the average thickness of the shell over the circumference. For the considered study, the function φ (α) has the form: φ (α) = 1 + δ α 2 , where δ is the amplitude of thickness variation. In general, H0 = H(α = 0) is the minimum value of φ(α) while H m = H(α = π /2) is the maximum value of φ(α), and in the case of δ = 0 the shell has constant thickness H0. The dependence of the shell thickness ratio ζ = Hm /H0 on δ has the form ζ = 1 + 2.47 δ. Suppose that the axial and circumferential directions are principal axes of the orthotropic material. Hereby, there exists the relation: (3) where Ex , Es are Young’s moduli and ν x , ν s are Poisson’s ratios in the axial and circumferential directions, respectively. Figure 1.
Coordinate system and geometry of an orthotropic oval cylindrical shell with circumferentially varying thickness.

sec.title: 2.2. Governing equations
sec.p: For general circular cylindrical shells and for studying the free harmonic vibrations, the equilibrium equations of forces, based on Flügge (1973) can be shown to be in the forms: (4) where Nx , Ns and Qx , Qs are the normal and transverse shearing forces in the x and s directions, respectively,Nsx and Nxs are the in-plane shearing forces, MX , Ms and Mxs , Msx are the bending moment and the twisting moment, respectively, Ss is the equivalent (Kelvin-Kirchoff) shearing force, ρ is the mass density, ω is the angular frequency of vibration, ′ ≡ ∂ / ∂ x, and • ≡ ∂ / ∂s. The relations between strains and deflections for the cylindrical shells used here are taken from Novozhilov (1964) and Uhrig (1973) as follows: (5) where εx and εs are the normal strains of the middle surface of the shell, γxs , γ xz and γsz are the shear strains, and the quantities Kx , Ks , Ksx and Kxs representing the change of curvature and the twist of the middle surface, ψx is the bending slope, and ψs is the angular rotation. The components of force and moment in terms of equation (5) are given as in Flügge (1973): (6) where the quantities Dx , Ds and Dxs are the extensional rigidities, and on considering the variable thickness of the shell, using equation (2), defined as: (7) And Kx , Ks, and Kxs are the flexural rigidities defined as: (8) in terms of Young’s moduli Ex and Es, Poisson’s ratios νx and νs, and the shear modulus G. The components of subscript zero denote the reference ones, chosen to be the averages on the middle surface of the shell over the circumference.

From equations (4) to (8), with eliminating the variables Qx , Qs , Nxs , Mx Mxs and Msx which are not differentiated with respect to s, the vibration system of the partial differential equations for the state variables u , ν , w , ψ s , Ms , Ss , Ns and Nsx of the shell are obtained as follows: (9)

For a simply supported shell, the solution of the system of equation (9) takes the forms: (10) where m is the axial half wave number and the quantities U¯(s),V¯(s) ,…,‥ are the state variables which are undetermined functions of s.

sec.title: 3. Basic form of the governing equations
sec.p: The differential equations as shown previously are modified to a suitable form and solved numerically. Hence, by substituting equation (10) into equation (9), after appropriate algebraic operations, the system of governing equations of the shell can be written in nonlinear ordinary differential equations referred to the variable s only are obtained, as in the following matrix: (11)
By using the state vector of fundamental unknowns Z(s), system (11) can be written as: (12)

For the non-circular cylindrical shell whose cross-section profile is obtained by function (r = r0 f(θ)), the hypotenuse (ds) of a right triangle whose sides are infinitesimal distances along the surface coordinates of the shell takes the form: (13)
Using equation (13), the system of vibration equation (12) takes the form: (14) where f2+f•2, and the coefficients matrix [V] are given as: (15)

V83 = φ3(1 – νxνs)/C, V85 = νs/Cη,V87 = – νs(mπ/l)/η in terms of the following dimensionless parameters: frequency parameter λ=r0ωρ(1−νxνs)/Ex,h0=H0/r0, length ratio l = L/r0 , reference thickness ratio h0 = H0 /r0, circumferential and axial orthotropic parameters η = Ds0 /Dx0 = Ks0 /Kx0 = νs νx and μ = Dxs0 /Dx0 = Kxs0 /Kx0 = G(1 − νx νs )/Ex, respectively, while B1 = 1 + Γ1(φ2 /C2 ) and Γ1=h02/12 .

sec.title: 3.1. Radius of curvature analysis
sec.p: As the solution of equation (14) drastically depends on the variable curvature R(θ), it follows that the radius of curvature should represent the actual geometry of the middle surface of the shell. In the present study, the radius of curvature is found to be in a complex form and can be arrived at from this equation: (16)

Using equations (1) and (16), the expression C = R(θ)/r0, in equations (15), can be found to take the form: (17) which represents the dimensionless radius of curvature of the oval shell considered here having more than one degree terms of ε and it means that the shell is not close to an elliptic shell. As well as the relation between the tangential angle, α and the central angle, θ is given as in Biing et al. (2009) as:

sec.title: 3.2. Matrix representation
sec.p: The state vector {Z(θ)} of fundamental unknowns can be easily expressed as: (18) by using the transfer matrix [Y(θ)] of the shell and the substitution of this expression into equation (14) performs to: (19)

The governing system of vibration (19) is too complicated to obtain any closed form solution, and this problem is highly favorable for solving by numerical methods. Hence, the matrix [Y(θ)] is obtained by using numerical integration, by use of the Romberg integration method, with the starting value [Y(0)] = [I] (unit matrix), which is given by taking θ = 0 in equation (18), and its solution depends only on the geometric and martial properties of the shell. For a plane passing through the central axis in a shell with structural symmetry, symmetrical and anti-symmetrical profiles can be obtained, and consequently, only one-half of the shell circumference is considered with the boundary conditions at the ends taken to be the symmetric or anti-symmetric type of vibration modes. Therefore, the boundary conditions for symmetrical and anti-symmetrical type-modes, respectively, are (20)

For any value of m, the natural modes of vibration of oval cylindrical shells which has a doubly symmetric profile may be classified as four different types of vibration modes (SS, SA, AA, AS), based on whether the modes are symmetric, S, or anti-symmetric, A, with respect to the minor and major axes of the shell at (θ = 0 or θ = π), and (θ = π/2 or θ = 3π/2), respectively.

sec.title: 4. Vibration frequencies and mode shapes equations
sec.p: The substitution of equation (20) into equation (18) results in the frequency equations as follows: (21) (22)

Equations (21) and (22) give a set of linear homogenous equations with unknown coefficients {U˜,W˜,M˜s,N˜s}(0)T and {V˜,ψ˜s,S˜s,N˜sx}0T, respectively, at θ = 0. For the existence of a non-trivial solution of these coefficients, the determinant of the coefficient matrix should be vanished. The standard procedures cannot be employed for obtaining the eigenvalues of the frequency parameter λ. The non-trivial solution is found by searching the values λ in matrix [Y(π)] which make its determinant zero by using the Lagrange interpolation procedure. The mode shapes of vibration at any point of the cross-section of the shell, for each axial half mode m are determined by calculating the eigenvectors corresponding to the eigenvalues λ by using Gaussian elimination procedure.

sec.title: 5. Computed results and discussion
sec.p: A computer program, based on the analysis described herein, was written to find the frequency parameters and the corresponding mode shapes of vibration for such shells in the presence of transfer matrix approach. Our study is divided into four parts in which the Poisson’s ratio νs and the axial rigidity μ take the values 0.3 and 0.35, respectively.

sec.title: 5.1. Verification of solution method
sec.p:
Table 1 presents the frequency parameters λ for an isotropic simply supported circular cylindrical shell of a constant thickness obtained by Loy et al. (1997) and Mumtaz (2009), who have obtained the solutions using a generalized differential quadrature method and a wave propagation method, respectively, and the author who has obtained the transfer matrix approach solutions based on Flügge’s shell theory using the Romberg integration method when ε = 0, η = 1 and μ = 0.35 that gives an isotropic cylindrical shell. We observe that the present solutions are in good agreement with these studies. The value of n in this table represents the mode sequence number of frequency parameters λ for m = 1. Simply using the curvature (r0 /R(s) = 1 + ε cos (2s/r0 )), i.e. this form of curvature represents a doubly symmetric oval configuration and approximates an ellipse having the same semi-major to semi-minor axis ratio as the oval, and for SS, SA, AA and AS type-modes of vibration. Table 2 presents the frequency parameters λ for an isotropic oval cylindrical shell of constant thickness obtained by Soldatos (1986) and Ganapathi et al. (2003) who have obtained the solutions based on parabolic shear deformation theory, and higher order shear deformation theory, respectively, using finite element approach, and the author. In general, the comparison studies have confirmed the correctness of the proposed shell theory and the solution method for studying vibration characteristics of such problems. Table 1.
Comparison of frequency parameters λ for a simply supported uniform circular cylindrical shell (l = 20, h0 = 0.01, ν = 0.3, m = 1)

sec.title: 5.3. Mode shapes of vibration
sec.p:
A vibration mode has been defined as the deflection of a structure at a particular frequency. To obtain the mode shapes of vibration corresponding to a particular frequency parameter λ of the shell, we substitute by λ into equations (21) and (22), and find the eigenvectors corresponding to λ using a Gaussian elimination procedure. Generally, the vibration mode is located at the weakest generatrix of the shell and becomes pronounced over the sections with reduced thicknesses at (θ = 0, π) where the shell has less stiffness. Figure 5 shows the circumferential vibration modes of an isotropic and orthotropic oval cylindrical shell for (SS, SA, AA, AS) type-modes to a set of ε values. The thick curves show the composition of the circumferential and transverse deflections on the shell surface and the dotted curves show the original shell shape before the vibration case. The numbers in the parentheses are the axial half wave numbers corresponding to the frequency parameters λ listed in Table 3. There are considerable differences between the modes of uniform (ζ = 1) and non-uniform shell for symmetrical and anti-symmetrical modes. For (η = 1), the vibration modes are distributed regularly over the shell surface, but for (ζ > 1), the majority of symmetric and anti-symmetric vibration modes are located at the reduced thickness (θ = 0 , π), with less stiffness, are larger than those at the biggest thickness, (θ = π /2, 3π /2), with more stiffness, i.e. the vibration modes are localized near the weakest lines on the shell surface. However, for each value of ζ, the deflections of the vibration mode in the weakest regions become more pronounced with higher ζ, and the deformation is the maximum at (θ = 0 , π). From Figure 4, no difference is observed for the isotropic and orthotropic form of mode shapes of vibration versus ζ and ε values. From these figures, the mode shapes of vibration are more sensitive to thickness ratio and ovality parameters than the axial and circumferential rigidities of the shell. It is also found that the mode shapes are similar in the sets of the vibration modes that have (m = 1, 2) for each value of η and μ. Figure 5.
The circumferential vibration modes of an oval cylindrical shell with circumferentially varying thickness (l = 4, h0 = 0.02, μ = 0.35) η = 0.5, η = 1 , η = 2.

sec.title: 5.4. Case study
sec.p:
We consider a special case for an orthotropic circular cylindrical shell of circumferentially variable thickness (ε = 0, ζ ≥ 1). Table 3, section 1, gives the fundamental frequency parameter λ versus the circumferential rigidity η and thickness ratio ζ. From this table, we see that the frequency parameters increase with an increase in both η and ζ. It is also seen that the frequency parameters of symmetric and anti-symmetric vibrations are the same for all the values of η considered here but for (ζ > 1) those are not the same values and the change in the difference between them becomes bigger with higher ζ. For the influence of thickness ratio on the frequency parameter λ, Figure 4(a) shows that the increase in ζ leads to an increase in λ, and the change in the variation of frequency parameter curves becomes bigger with higher ζ. Figure 6 shows the circumferential symmetric and anti-symmetric modes of a circular cylindrical shell at several sets of ζ and η values. One can see from this figure that the vibration modes become uniformly distributed over the shell surface when the shell has constant thickness (ζ = 1), and the deflections of the vibration modes in the weakest thickness at (θ = 0 , π) become more pronounced with larger ζ for each η value, and the shell becomes much more vibrational for the isotropic and anisotropic modes. Coupling of circumferential modes, corresponding to circular cylindrical shell, is significant for eccentric shell vibrating at modes with axial wave numbers (m = 1, 2). Figure 6.
The circumferential vibration modes of an isotropic and orthotropic circular cylindrical shell having variable thickness. (l = 4, h0 = 0.02, μ = 0.35).

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: An approximate analysis for studying the vibration behavior of an elastic oval cylindrical shell having circumferentially variable thickness dependent on the tangential angle is presented. The computed results presented herein find the vibration frequencies and the corresponding mode shapes of the deflection displacements for four type-modes of vibration (SS, SA, AA, AS). New results are obtained for such shells which have radius of curvature containing more than one degree terms of the ovality parameter. The fundamental frequency parameters were found to be unidentical for the symmetric and anti-symmetric modes of vibration for oval cylindrical shells, unlike the case of circular cylinders with constant thickness. The frequency parameter values increase with an increase in the range of axial and circumferential rigidities beside the thickness ratio of the shell. The vibration frequencies were found to increase and the mode shapes become more pronounced at the weakest surface of the shell when the thickness ratio increases. The ovality parameter ε of the considered shell can affect the values of vibration frequencies λ. In general, the study showed that the eccentricity parameter decreases the frequency parameter for (ε ≤ 4) and increases it for (ε > 4) and becomes larger for circular cylindrical shells. The study also showed that the deformations’ corresponding frequency parameters are located and concentrated at the less stiffened zones of the shell surface, and become more pronounced with an increase in thickness ratio value. Finally, it is worth mentioning that the shells of circumferentially variable thickness will undergo larger deformation than the uniform shells, due to their low stiffness of reduced thickness parts.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The author is grateful to the anonymous reviewers for their kind efforts and valuable comments, which helped improve the quality of this paper.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
